i'm not in a union and i work in a specialized area but i'm the principle welder and a leading carpenter in my current shop at work. i'm leaving in a couple months to get an MFA so i've got a little bit of short-timer[.] syndrome at the moment haha.

because i work in the arts, although my department tends to interest more men than women, it[.] likely much less of a Good Ol' Boys' club than the more regulated trades are. i've only encountered a few guys who had no faith in my ability because of my sex, and the vast majority of men i've worked with who've been doing this longer have been happy to share their experience with me and teach me at any given opportunity.  it[.] very rare anything[.] "mansplained" and there[.] generally enough snark/tough skin amongst employees that if someone is being kind of an asshole, it[.] ok to let them know that.

i feel lucky that i've been able to work with so many people who are enthusiastic about sharing their craft and pointing out when there are better ways to do things. i recently saw someone i hadn't seen for 5 years who was an employee at one of the first places i worked professionally, and it really hit me how much i've been able to learn and accomplish in 5 years, VERY much thanks to the good people who have helped guide me since i became interested in construction.
